G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises under, inter alia, G.L. c. 186, § 14 (covenant of quiet enjoyment), and related Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and has controlled and been responsible for the repair and maintenance of the building systems serving the Premises, including electrical wiring and outlets.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 if statutory trebling under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is awarded, and because this is a civil action in which equitable and legal relief are sought for violations of Massachusetts landlord-tenant law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Hampden Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 because the Premises are located in Hampden County and the events giving rise to this action occurred in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code requires landlords to maintain electrical facilities in good repair. See G.L. c. 111, § 127A; 105 C.M.R. 410.351 (requiring safe, adequate electrical service and outlets in habitable rooms).

105 C.M.R. 410.351.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code requires landlords to maintain electrical facilities in good repair. See G.L. c. 111, § 127A; 105 C.M.R. 410.351 (requiring safe, adequate electrical service and outlets in habitable rooms).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Plaintiff’s claim is further consistent with Massachusetts’ public policy of ensuring safe, habitable rental housing and protecting residential tenants from substantial interference with their-tenancy due to a landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions, as reflected in G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 15F; and cases such as Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 196–98 (1973), which recognize the landlord’s non‑waivable duty to provide premises that meet basic standards of habitability and essential services.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u00a7 14, 15F.proposition: Plaintiff’s claim is further consistent with Massachusetts’ public policy of ensuring safe, habitable rental housing and protecting residential tenants from substantial interference with their-tenancy due to a landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions, as reflected in G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 15F; and cases such as Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 196–98 (1973), which recognize the landlord’s non‑waivable duty to provide premises that meet basic standards of habitability and essential services.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by G.L. c. 231, § 6B and other applicable statutes;

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment codified in G.L. c. 186, § 14 protects tenants from substantial interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s actions or failures to act. See Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–19 (1977).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 to a landlord’s failure to provide heat and explicitly characterizes that failure as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, citing Blackett and related authority. The court explains that liability under § 14 turns on the landlord’s conduct and the natural and probable consequences for the tenant’s rights, which necessarily protects tenants from substantial interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s actions or failures to act (here, not furnishing heat). Thus the case directly supports the stated proposition about the scope of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment codified in G.L. c. 186, § 14 protects tenants from substantial interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s actions or failures to act. See Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–19 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion is decided under the common‑law implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, not expressly under G.L. c. 186, § 14. However, it clearly holds that a landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when substantial interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment flows as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, including failing to control a noisy lounge they introduced and could control. That principle is the same substantive rule later described as embodied in the statutory covenant, so the case provides supporting authority by analogy, though not as a construction of the statute itself.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Interference with essential services or conditions that materially impair the character and value of the leased premises constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Blackett, 371 Mass. at 715–19; Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly defines a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as serious interference that impairs the character and value of the leasehold, and applies that standard to non-physical conditions (pervasive criminal/drug activity) that effectively deprive tenants of the use of essential parts of the premises. While the case does not use the term “essential services,” it clearly holds that conditions that seriously interfere with tenants’ ability to use common areas and thereby substantially impair the character of the leased premises can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. This aligns with the proposition that such interferences amount to a breach.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that a landlord’s failure to remedy serious defects within the premises, including defects affecting heat, electricity, or basic habitability, can amount to a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–06 (1982); Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–52 (1997).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, habitable conditions—here, repeated flooding with water and sewage in violation of the State Sanitary Code—can constitute an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court discusses quiet enjoyment in the context of serious habitability defects and expressly concludes that Gem’s failure to prevent repeated flooding that violated its duty to maintain sanitary conditions rendered it liable under the quiet enjoyment statute, thereby linking habitability-type defects to quiet enjoyment violations.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that a landlord’s failure to remedy serious defects within the premises, including defects affecting heat, electricity, or basic habitability, can amount to a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–06 (1982); Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–52 (1997).
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment but in the specific context of whether a statutory lead‑paint violation, without fault, automatically constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. It holds that at least negligent conduct with notice is required and expressly focuses on lead paint, not on failures to repair heat, electricity, or other basic habitability defects. While the court cites Simon and other cases (where serious habitability defects did violate quiet enjoyment), Al‑Ziab itself does not establish or apply that principle; it merely restates that landlord negligence with notice can violate § 14 and rejects strict liability for lead‑paint violations alone.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings…”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–02 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Material violations of the Sanitary Code may also support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–02 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the implied warranty of habitability, rent abatement, and the effect of State Sanitary Code violations on habitability, but it does not address or analyze a statutory or common-law claim for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 or otherwise. The cited pages make the point that substantial Sanitary Code violations render a dwelling uninhabitable for warranty purposes, not that such violations independently support a quiet-enjoyment claim. Using Berman for that specific proposition overstates its holding.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, supra at 196-197. A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water.” (379 Mass. at 201–02)

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 196–98 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Plaintiff’s claim is further consistent with Massachusetts’ public policy of ensuring safe, habitable rental housing and protecting residential tenants from substantial interference with their-tenancy due to a landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions, as reflected in G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 15F; and cases such as Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 196–98 (1973), which recognize the landlord’s non‑waivable duty to provide premises that meet basic standards of habitability and essential services.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurrence/dissent, not the majority, but it expressly grounds a landlord’s obligations in Massachusetts public policy reflected in the State Sanitary Code and G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and treats these minimum standards as non‑waivable. Justice Quirico states that statutes and the Code impose on landlords, for the benefit of tenants, an obligation to comply with minimum standards of fitness for habitation, and that agreements to waive enforcement rights are void as against public policy. That supports the proposition that Massachusetts public policy ensures safe, habitable housing and protects tenants against substantial interference arising from serious uncorrected conditions, though it does so via statutory/code-based obligations rather than a broad, free‑standing “warranty of habitability.”
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units. The Code is not solely penal in nature. By G. L. c. 111, § 127C… and § 127H… a tenant may file a petition… to enforce compliance with the Code by the landlord; and by § 127K… any agreement by the tenant to waive that right is declared to be against public policy and void.”
